title: 107_s2449
content: The Act titled "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" allows federal payments under Medicaid for emergency medical conditions of certain aliens. The Social Security Act is amended to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and communicable disease testing or treatment for certain aliens. Additionally, states have the option to eliminate residency requirements for aliens granted parole or admitted as nonimmigrant aliens. The amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act eliminate residency requirements for certain aliens receiving medical assistance under the State plan. The effective date for these amendments is the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is allocated as follows: $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2001, and $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007. The Secretary of Health and Human Services determines allotments for the 15 states with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 to 2007. The funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is allocated to the 15 states with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens. The allotment for each state is based on the ratio of the percentage of undocumented aliens in the state to the total percentage for all states. Any unspent allotment from a fiscal year is available for payment in the following fiscal year. The Statistics Division of the Immigration and Naturalization Service prepares a report on the alien population in each state. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to require funds to assist hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens in states impacted by health costs related to undocumented aliens. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide funds for hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens based on their payments under the State plan approved under title XIX of the Social Security Act or an alternative proxy for measuring the volume of services. Definitions and special rules apply to hospitals, providers, and emergency ambulance services. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide funds for hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens based on their payments under the State plan approved under title XIX of the Social Security Act or an alternative proxy for measuring the volume of services. Definitions and special rules apply to hospitals, providers, and emergency ambulance services, with amendments effective from fiscal year 2003. SEC. 4. Permitting states and localities to provide health care to all individuals. Amendments are made to Section 411 of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, including changes to subsections (b) and (c). The amendments exclude health benefits provided by state or local government agencies from the definition of "health benefit." Effective date of the amendments is specified. The amendments made to Section 411 of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 exclude health benefits provided by state or local government agencies. The effective date of these amendments applies to health care furnished before, on, or after the enactment of the Act.
